asClass.name: BitmapRenderer
asClass.description: The BitmapRenderer actually draws the particles and all the animations as a single bitmap. This allows you to enabled filters to give really interesting effects which woudl only be possible as a bitmap.
asClass.shortDescription: The BitmapRenderer actually draws the particles and all the animations as a single bitmap.

method.name: clear
method.description: Clears the renderer.
method.shortDescription: Clears the renderer.

method.name: getPalletteMap
method.description: Gets the palletemap if it was set. If it wasn't set, it will just return an empty or null array.
method.shortDescription: Gets the palletemap if it was set.
method.result: An array of the pallette colors.

method.name: pause
method.description: Pauses the renderer
method.shortDescription: Pauses the renderer

method.name: play
method.description: Resumes or plays the renderer
method.shortDescription: Resumes or plays the renderer

method.name: render
method.description: Calls the renderer to draw the particles.
method.shortDescription: Calls the renderer to draw the particles.

param.name: e
param.description: The emitter associated with the particles.

method.name: setPalletteMap
method.description: Remaps the color channel values in an image that has up to four arrays of color palette data, one for each channel.
method.shortDescription: Remaps the color channel values in an image that has up to four arrays of color palette data, one for each channel.

param.name: red
param.description: If redArray is not null, red = redArray[source red value] else red = source rect value.

param.name: green
param.description: If greenArray is not null, green = greenArray[source green value] else green = source green value.

param.name: blue
param.description: If blueArray is not null, blue = blueArray[source blue value] else blue = source blue value.

param.name: alpha
param.description: If alphaArray is not null, alpha = alphaArray[source alpha value] else alpha = source alpha value.

method.description: Clears and inits the bitmap data once it has access to the stage.
method.shortDescription: Clears and inits the bitmap data once it has access to the stage.

field.shortDescription: An array of items to be drawn to th renderer.

field.description: Fitlers that will be applied after new particles have been drawn to the bitmap.
field.shortDescription: Fitlers that will be applied after new particles have been drawn to the bitmap.

field.description: Filters that will be applied before new particles are drawn to the bitmap.
field.shortDescription: Filters that will be applied before new particles are drawn to the bitmap.

asClass.name: PixelRenderer
asClass.description: The PixelRenderer class acts exactly like the BitmapRenderer class. The one difference is that instead of drawing particles to the bitmap, it will draw a single pixel for each particles in the Orion instance.
asClass.shortDescription: The PixelRenderer class acts exactly like the BitmapRenderer class.

asClass.name: BurstOutput
asClass.description: The BurstOutput class adds the specified number of particles all at once, then doesn't add any new particles. This is useful if you want to just setup a system of say 10 particles and leave it a that.
asClass.shortDescription: The BurstOutput class adds the specified number of particles all at once, then doesn't add any new particles.

method.name: pause
method.shortDescription: Pauses the output class.

method.name: play
method.shortDescription: Resumes or plays the output class.

method.name: update
method.shortDescription: This is called everytime the particles are called to update and be redrawn.

constructor.description: Controls the number of particles that are emitted.
constructor.shortDescription: Controls the number of particles that are emitted.

param.name: numOfParticles
param.description: How manu particles to add at once.

asClass.name: SteadyOutput
asClass.description: The SteadyOutput class outputs particles at a predictable rate. This is useful if you just want particles to be outputted and don't care for anything fancy.
asClass.shortDescription: The SteadyOutput class outputs particles at a predictable rate.

asClass.name: FunctionOutput
asClass.description: The FunctionOutput class emits particles based on the given function. This allows you to pulse ouput of particles just by passing in a function that does that. Or if you wanted to create a sine output, create a function that handles that. This class is very flexible if used correctly.
asClass.shortDescription: The FunctionOutput class emits particles based on the given function.

constructor.name: OrionBitmap
constructor.description: The constructor allows a few common settings to be specified during construction. Options such as the output class or any configuration settings.
constructor.shortDescription: The constructor allows a few common settings to be specified during construction.

param.name: spriteClass
param.description: This is the linkage class of the item you have exported from the library.

param.name: output
param.description: Here you can specify which output class you'd like to use. If you don't want to use one, just leave this as null

param.name: config
param.description: Here you can pass in a configuration object. A configuration object is generated by a preset or you can write one by hand. Each configuration object can contain an effectFilters array, an edgeFilter object, and a settings object. The settings object can contain all the same properties that modifying the settings property directly allows.

param.name: useFrameCaching
param.description: Frame caching is useful for particles that have a lot of glow filters or native Flash filters applied. Turning on frame caching will cause Orion to take a snapshot of each frame of the particle and turn it into a Bitmap and use the Bitmap instead. This can greatly increase performance for complicated particles.

method.name: getCoordinate
method.description: Returns a coordinate it's designated position.
method.shortDescription: Returns a coordinate it's designated position.
method.result: Returns a coordinate at the emitters x,y position or within it.

method.name: render
method.description: Updates all the particles and positions, updates the output class as well.
method.shortDescription: Updates all the particles and positions, updates the output class as well.

param.name: e
param.description: The event dispatched.

method.name: updateBitmap
method.description: Updates the bitmapdata of the target display object if it has changed.
method.shortDescription: Updates the bitmapdata of the target display object if it has changed.

method.name: updateIntersection
method.description: Update the intersecting rectangle. Only emit particles within the emitter and within the bounds of the image.
method.shortDescription: Update the intersecting rectangle.

field.name: isRandom
field.description: If true, it ignores speedX and speedY and randomly chooses a point within the emitter.
field.shortDescription: If true, it ignores speedX and speedY and randomly chooses a point within the emitter.

field.name: speedX
field.description: The X speed that the emitter scans the bitmap and adds particles.
field.shortDescription: The X speed that the emitter scans the bitmap and adds particles.

field.name: speedY
field.description: The Y speed that the emitter scans the bitmap and adds particles.
field.shortDescription: The Y speed that the emitter scans the bitmap and adds particles.

field.name: target
field.description: The display object to use as a reference for the bitmapdata. This is the object that is actually drawn from and the dimensions are grabbed from. If no target is specified, then it will default to the parent of the emitter.
field.shortDescription: The display object to use as a reference for the bitmapdata.

field.name: targetColor
field.description: The target color to attach particles to within the bitmap.
field.shortDescription: The target color to attach particles to within the bitmap.

asClass.name: Orion
asClass.description:
Orion ©2009 Gabriel Mariani, coursevector.com.
Visit http://blog.coursevector.com/orion for documentation, updates and more free code.
Licensed under the MIT license - see the source file header for more information.
Orion is an easy to use and light-weight particle system. It's instance oriented much like GTween so you can re-use and modify easily. It's also very fast, capable of handling over 3000 particles at more than 30fps if your computer can handle it. But unless you're doing something really intense you probably won't notice any slowdown. At it's smallest Orion will add about 6kb to your filesize.

The Orion class is the hub of particle system. It determines where the particles will be generated. All particles are generated within the bounds of the Orion instance. So if you set it up to be 100x100, the particles will be generated somewhere within that area. If you set the width and height below 1 (i.e. 0x0), it will generate all the particles at the center of the instance.

To control where the particles can be displayed you can modify the canvas property. The canvas is a simple rectange object, changing the height, width, and position of it will determine where the particles will be displayed and when the edgeFilter will take action.

Orion is easy to use and incredibly flexible and customizable. To keep it's size down, there are effectFilters, the more you add the more work Orion has to do which can affect performance and filesize. So keep this in mind before you use every filter and wonder why it's not handling 3000 particles easily. Below are some examples to show you how to use Orion and how quickly you can get up and running. Since Orion is so customizable, I thought it would be nice to be able to save those configurations so you can use the same settings again. This is what the presets are used for. They will configure an instance of Orion with the given settings. If you have to find a setting you like you can create your own presets and load them as well.
asClass.shortDescription: <strong>Orion ©2009 Gabriel Mariani, coursevector.com.
asClass.example:
The only requirement to use Orion is to have an item exported from the library.

import cv.Orion; import cv.orion.preset.Default; // A small set of common presets var e:Orion = new Orion(linkageClass, null, Default.firework()); this.addChild(e);

That's it! Although that is a very basic setup but as you can see, it doesn't take much work to get a particle system up and running in your code.

constructor.name: Orion
constructor.description: The constructor allows a few common settings to be specified during construction. Options such as the output class or any configuration settings.
constructor.shortDescription: The constructor allows a few common settings to be specified during construction.

param.name: spriteClass
param.description: This is the linkage class of the item you have exported from the library.

param.name: output
param.description: Here you can specify which output class you'd like to use. If you don't want to use one, just leave this as null

param.name: config
param.description: Here you can pass in a configuration object. A configuration object is generated by a preset or you can write one by hand. Each configuration object can contain an effectFilters array, an edgeFilter object, and a settings object. The settings object can contain all the same properties that modifying the settings property directly allows.

param.name: useFrameCaching
param.description: Frame caching is useful for particles that have a lot of glow filters or native Flash filters applied. Turning on frame caching will cause Orion to take a snapshot of each frame of the particle and turn it into a Bitmap and use the Bitmap instead. This can greatly increase performance for complicated particles.

method.name: addParticle
method.description: Adds a new particle to the system. Before creating a new particle, it will check the recycle bin of old particles to see if it can match the particle requested. If so, it will re-use an old particle rather than create a new one as this is quicker on the player.
method.shortDescription: Adds a new particle to the system.

param.name: pt
param.description: The point to position the particle at.

method.name: cacheFramesOf
method.description: If it's a movieclip, cache it's frames.
method.shortDescription: If it's a movieclip, cache it's frames.

param.name: mc
param.description: The particle to have it's frames cached.

method.name: emit
method.description: Causes the emitter to add particles.
method.shortDescription: Causes the emitter to add particles.

param.name: point
param.description: Where to position the particle

field.name: canvas
field.description: The canvas is used to control the boundaries (edge filter) of the particles animating.
field.shortDescription: The canvas is used to control the boundaries (edge filter) of the particles animating.

field.name: createEmitters
field.description:
Triggers the emitters everytime a particle from this emitter is created. This allows for effects like the explosion before a firework goes up.
This array can only accept instances of the Orion class.
When using this, specify the output of the child emitter to the parent emitter.
field.shortDescription: Triggers the emitters everytime a particle from this emitter is created.

field.name: debug
field.description: Turns on debug lines to outline the emitter and canvas dimensions
field.shortDescription: Turns on debug lines to outline the emitter and canvas dimensions

field.name: destroyEmitters
field.description:
Triggers the emitters everytime a particle from this emitter is destroyed. This allows for effects like the explosion after a firework goes up.
This array can only accept instances of the Orion class.
When using this, specify the output of the child emitter to the parent emitter.
field.shortDescription: Triggers the emitters everytime a particle from this emitter is destroyed.

field.name: edgeFilter
field.description: Gets or sets the edge filter used by the emitter to determine what the particles will do when they hit the edge. Pass nothing to it in order to reset it.
field.shortDescription: Gets or sets the edge filter used by the emitter to determine what the particles will do when they hit the edge.

field.name: effectFilters
field.description: Gets the filters being applied by the emitter.
field.shortDescription: Gets the filters being applied by the emitter.

field.name: output
field.description: Gets or sets the output class used. The default is the null.
field.shortDescription: Gets or sets the output class used.

field.name: particlesVisible
field.description: As the particles are updated, this will toggle visibility on or off. Used by the BitmapRenderer/PixelRenderer so it can hide the particles without additional overhead.
field.shortDescription: As the particles are updated, this will toggle visibility on or off.

field.name: settings
field.description:
The settings object controls all configuration. The settings object can contain the following properties :

  • lifeSpan:int - The lifespan of the particle in milliseconds. After that time is up, it is removed from display. (In milliseconds)
  • mass:Number - The mass of a particle. The larger, the harder it is to move.
  • opacity:Number - The initial alpha of a particle. From 0 to 1.
  • opacityMin:Number - The minimum alpha in a range for the particle randomly initially. From 0 to 1.
  • opacityMax:Number - The maximum alpha in a range for the particle randomly initially. From 0 to 1.
  • velocityX:Number - The initial X velocity of a particle.
  • velocityXMin:Number - The minimum X velocity in a range to move the particle randomly initially.
  • velocityXMax:Number - The maximum X velocity in a range to move the particle randomly initially.
  • velocityY:Number - The initial Y velocity of a particle.
  • velocityYMin:Number - The minimum Y velocity in a range to move the particle randomly initially.
  • velocityYMax:Number - The maximum Y velocity in a range to move the particle randomly initially.
  • velocityRotate:Number - The initial spinning velocity of a particle.
  • velocityRotateMin:Number - The minimum spin in a range to spin the particle randomly initially.
  • velocityRotateMax:Number - The maximum spin in a range to spin the particle randomly initially.
  • velocityAngle:Number - The direction the particle will move in. From 0 to 360.
  • velocityAngleMin:Number - The minimum angle in a range to move in a random direction. From 0 to 360.
  • velocityAngleMax:Number - The maximum angle in a range to move in a random direction. From 0 to 360.
  • rotate:Number - The initial rotation of a particle. From 0 to 360.
  • rotateMin:Number - The minimum rotation in a range to rotate the particle randomly initially. From 0 to 360.
  • rotateMax:Number - The maximum rotation in a range to rotate the particle randomly initially. From 0 to 360.
  • scale:Number - The initial scale of a particle.
  • scaleMin:Number - The minimum scale in a range to scale the particle randomly initially.
  • scaleMax:Number - The maximum scale in a range to scale the particle randomly initially.
  • color:int - The initial tint of a particle.
  • colorMin:int - The minimum color in a range to tint the particle randomly initially.
  • colorMax:int - The maximum color in a range to tint the particle randomly initially.
  • selectRandomFrame:Boolean - If a frame is randomly selected initially.
  • numberOfParticles:Number - How many particles to create each time a particle is emitted.
field.shortDescription: The settings object controls all configuration.

field.description: Current Time

field.name: updateEmitters
field.description:
Triggers the emitters everytime a particle from this emitter gets updated. This allows for effects like trailing smoke of a particle.
This array can only accept instances of the Orion class.
When using this, specify the output of the child emitter to the parent emitter.

field.name: useCacheAsBitmap
field.description: Gets or sets whether bitmap caching is enabled on particles used within this emitter. If set to true, Flash Player or Adobe AIR caches an internal bitmap representation of the display object. This caching can increase performance for display objects that contain complex vector content.
field.shortDescription: Gets or sets whether bitmap caching is enabled on particles used within this emitter.

field.description: Gets or sets whether frame caching will be enabled. Frame caching takes a snapshot of each frame of a movieclip and stores the bitmaps in an array. This bitmapdata is used later for new particles. This can greatly improve performance on occasion (especially movieclips with lots of fiters used inside or multiple frames).

asClass.name: OrionContainer
asClass.description:
OrionContainer takes a movieclip and animates the children inside of it as if they were particles. Does not add any new particles to the system.
Also any changes to the dimensions or position of the emitter are ignored.
asClass.shortDescription: OrionContainer takes a movieclip and animates the children inside of it as if they were particles.

constructor.name: OrionContainer
constructor.description:
The constructor for OrionContainer is slightly different from Orion. You cannot specify an output class becuase it is not used by OrionContainer. No new particles are created so there is nothing to output. Secondly you cannot specify framecaching becuase again, no new particles are created while this runs.
When the constructor runs, the canvas is automatically set to the stage dimensions (if available) and corrects for the target's position.
In debug mode, the emitter is positioned according to the coordinates of the target's parent. For the emitter to be positioned accurately, OrionContainer must be attached to the same DisplayObject as the target. This is only for the debug lines to be accurate, it's not required for anything else.
constructor.shortDescription: The constructor for OrionContainer is slightly different from Orion.

param.name: target
param.description: The display object to use.

param.name: config
param.description: Whether to add the target or the children inside the target.

param.description: Where to position the particle

asClass.name: DragFilter
asClass.description: The DragFilter determines how easily a particle moves around. The lower the number the easier it can move, the higher the number, the slower it moves.
asClass.shortDescription: The DragFilter determines how easily a particle moves around.

customs.internal:
If on a flat surface F = Force of Friciton u = Coefficient of Friction N = Normal Force = mg m = Mass g = Gravity F = uN = umg = (0.3)(1,000kg)(9.8 meters per second2) = 2,940N
If on an incline N = mg cos{theta} F = mg sin{theta} + uN
We can take mass into account but we can't really take gravity becuase this class can't find out what that value is. So in lieu of normal force (N) we're going to use the current force... yes I know, it's wrong but it should look fine for the purposes of Orion. This is really a fake version of friction which simulates it well enough.

asClass.name: TargetsGravityFilter
asClass.description:
The TargetsGravityFilter causes particles to attract to multiple targets. The targets added won't be moved by Orion, so when a particle hits, it will bounce off of them without pushing the target away.

Using the TargetsGravityFilter, you could easily setup a plantery system and actually have planets orbit around each other.

asClass.name: IFilter
asClass.description:
Implement the IFilter interface to create a custom particle filter. A particle filter applies a specific force or action to be applied to the particle.

Such forces could be gravity, a spring motion, or even fading the particle. The combination of these filters are strung together to form an effect.
asClass.shortDescription: Implement the IFilter interface to create a custom particle filter.

method.description: Applies the specified filter to a particular particle.
method.shortDescription: Applies the specified filter to a particular particle.

param.description: The individual particle.

param.name: target
param.description: The emitter associated with the particle.

asClass.name: IOutput
asClass.description:
Implement the IOutput interface to create a custom output class. An output class controls how fast and how many particles are emitted from the emitter. The default is SteadyOutput with the default rating.

Output classes can vary in capabilities, but ultimately choose the one that suites your needs. More often than not, the SteadyOutput will accomplish your goals.
asClass.shortDescription: Implement the IOutput interface to create a custom output class.
